Literature Review: The electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) to valuable chemicals and fuels is a promising pathway to mitigate climate change and reduce dependence on fossil fuels. This process, driven by renewable energy, is pivotal for achieving net-zero carbon emissions. A deep understanding of the structureâ€“activity relationship and the reaction mechanism is essential for enhancing the selectivity and efficiency of electrocatalysts. In situ/operando characterization techniques have emerged as powerful tools to study the dynamic evolution of catalysts and reaction intermediates under actual reaction conditions, providing mechanistic insights that are crucial for the rational design of more effective catalysts. This literature review focuses on the recent advancements in in situ/operando techniques for studying the electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), including surface-enhanced vibrational spectroscopies, X-ray- and electron-based techniques, and mass spectroscopy, and discusses the challenges and future directions in this field. Surface-enhanced vibrational spectroscopies, such as surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS), have been widely used to investigate the adsorption and reaction of CO2 on catalyst surfaces. These techniques provide valuable information on the nature of reaction intermediates and the changes in the catalyst surface during the reaction. For instance, SERS has been employed to study the CO2RR on gold and silver catalysts, revealing the formation of CO and formate as key intermediates (Chen et al., 2019). Similarly, SEIRAS has been used to monitor the dynamic changes in the catalyst surface and the electrolyte interface during CO2RR, offering insights into the reaction mechanism and the role of the electrolyte (Huang et al., 2020). X-ray-based techniques, including X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and X-ray diffraction (XRD), are powerful tools for probing the electronic structure and the atomic arrangement of catalysts under reaction conditions. Operando XAS has been utilized to study the oxidation state and coordination environment of metal centers in CO2RR catalysts, providing evidence for the dynamic changes in the catalyst structure during the reaction (Zhang et al., 2021). Operando XRD, on the other hand, has been used to monitor the phase transformations and the formation of new phases in catalysts during CO2RR, which are critical for understanding the catalyst stability and activity (Wang et al., 2022). Electron-based techniques, such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), have been employed to visualize the morphological changes and the evolution of catalyst nanostructures under reaction conditions. In situ TEM has been used to observe the restructuring of copper catalysts during CO2RR, revealing the formation of active sites and the role of defects in enhancing the catalytic activity (Li et al., 2020). Mass spectroscopy, particularly differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS), has been used to identify and quantify the gaseous and liquid products of CO2RR in real-time, providing a comprehensive understanding of the reaction pathways and the selectivity of different catalysts (Ross et al., 2019). Despite the significant progress in in situ/operando characterization techniques, several challenges remain. The complexity of the CO2RR, involving multiple reaction pathways and intermediates, requires the development of more sophisticated techniques that can provide simultaneous information on the catalyst structure, the reaction intermediates, and the product distribution. Moreover, the harsh reaction conditions, including high overpotentials and the presence of reactive species, pose challenges for the stability and sensitivity of the characterization techniques. Future research should focus on the integration of multiple in situ/operando techniques to obtain a holistic understanding of the CO2RR and the development of new techniques with higher spatial and temporal resolution. In conclusion, in situ/operando characterization techniques have provided unprecedented insights into the electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction, enabling the rational design of more efficient and selective catalysts. The continued development and integration of these techniques will be crucial for advancing our understanding of the CO2RR and accelerating the transition to a sustainable energy future.
